title: 7 things you didn't know about the making of the Netflix's 'Breaking Bad' movie
text:
Jesse Plemons improvised the "honk the horn" gesture during the scene when Todd Alquist drove out to the desert to bury a body

Jesse Plemons in "El Camino." Netflix

In the film, Jesse stuffed Todd in the back of his car and drove them out to the desert to bury Sonia, a maid who discovered that Todd had stacks of drug money hidden in his apartment's encyclopedias. She was killed because of the revelation.

While driving, Todd sang "Sharing the Night Together" and made the arm gesture at a truck zooming by. The action seemed perfectly in line with the bizarre character, and it was all Plemons' idea.

"That was not scripted," Gilligan told Vulture. "When he did it, I was riding in this big giant truck that tows the car that Jesse [Plemons] is pretending to be driving. I'm watching on a monitor, it's cold outside so you're bundled up, and I'm huddled next to my director of photography and script supervisor."

Gilligan said that when Plemons did the "honk the horn" move while singing, he "almost fell out of the truck" from his laughter.

"He nailed it in one take," the director said. "It was such a thing of beauty. And our camera operator, thank God, he can contain his laughter, because he operated it perfectly."
description: Six years after the AMC drama ended, Aaron Paul reprised his role as Jesse for the film sequel. Here are some things you didn't know about the movie.
